issue.title: Add ntruprime
issue.body:
The purpose of the pr is to add the ntruprime key exchange algorithm.

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)
* [ ] 
Yes this pr add ntruprime to the available algorithm for key exchange algorithm

Thank you.

comment.body:
One more thought: Please add an explicit statement that "sntrup761" is only included until it is not needed for interop testing any more. The statement that it shall be removed if broken already is implicit in the language at https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs#limitations-and-security -- so maybe it might be suitable to add the "needed-for-interop" statement also there. Agreed, @dstebila ?
Finally, please feel free to add yourself to https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/CONTRIBUTORS, @ryndia

issue.title: Add NTRU prime back
issue.body:
Hi All,

We have been working on NTRU prime due to its interesting properties that make it an alternative choice to Kyber, despite its lack of NIST support. 

It would be worth pointing out that 
1) OpenSSH 9.0 (SSH server) ships with NTRU prime by default: https://www.openssh.com/txt/release-9.0
2) OpenIKED (VPN) ships with NTRU prime as well: https://github.com/openiked/openiked-portable/releases/tag/v7.0
3) Putty (SSH Client) now supports NTRU prime: https://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/changes.html

And the removal of NTRU prime breaks a popular SSH library which relies on liboqs-python for interop with OpenSSH:
https://github.com/ronf/asyncssh

A PR was sent for your consideration as well: https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1328

comment.body: I wanted to update the thread with a pointer to the message from the NTRU Prime team on the CFRG thread where an I-D is being discussed: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cfrg/bkIRllgoqNIpureewvCjDH2FIag/

issue.title: Remove boringssl interop testing
issue.body: Given (oqs-)boringssl apparently does not receive the same level of "care and attention" as oqs-openssl111 would it be reasonable to remove the [interop-test](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/5118e6ecd001db20936a753ec5013551ab3a93fb/.circleci/config.yml#L97-L124) with it? It always breaks when algorithms get changed in `liboqs` without prior proper downstream preparation.

comment.body: I agree, we are treating BoringSSL as a second-tier project for now, and we don't want its limitations to negatively impact first-tier projects like OpenSSL.  So it also makes sense to put the onus of interop testing in BoringSSL.

issue.title: remove boringssl interop
issue.body:
Fixes #416 

- [no] documentation is added or updated
- [x] tests are added or updated

comment.body: We could also just remove the `oqs-interop-test` directory if we're removing this job.

issue.title: remove boringssl interop
issue.body:
Fixes #416 

- [no] documentation is added or updated
- [x] tests are added or updated

comment.body:
> We could also just remove the `oqs-interop-test` directory if we're removing this job.

Well, my intention was not to completely remove this test capability, just to move it out of the critical (CI) path. What about removing it here/in oqs-openssl when it has been added to oqs-boringssl?

issue.title: Unable to run docker container for wireshark
issue.body:
Hello

I'm unable to run oqs-wireshark as a docker container.

I have used the below command, which is specified in the README,

```
docker run --net=host --privileged --env="DISPLAY" --volume="$HOME/.Xauthority:/root/.Xauthority:rw" openquantumsafe/wireshark
```


And I'm getting this error,

```
No protocol specified
21:23:24.408     Main Warn could not connect to display :0
21:23:24.408     Main Info Could not load the Qt platform plugin "xcb" in "" even though it was found.
Aborted (core dumped)
```

Kindly please help me with this error.

Thanks in advance.

comment.body: Adding in here that I'm working through the same error for Ubuntu 20.04. `xeyes` does work, though.

comment.body: Thanks @dstebila for marking the conversation resolved. For some reason, there's still a blocking "Changes requested" marker, though... Did I overlook something?

> Adding in here that I'm working through the same error for Ubuntu 20.04. `xeyes` does work, though.

`xeyes` is not Qt-based if I'm not mistaken (?), so may I suggest you first try running any (other) Qt-app in your environment, ideally from another docker setup? If that works we may be able to determine the differences to our setup.

issue.title: Unable to run docker container for wireshark
issue.body:
Hello

I'm unable to run oqs-wireshark as a docker container.

I have used the below command, which is specified in the README,

```
docker run --net=host --privileged --env="DISPLAY" --volume="$HOME/.Xauthority:/root/.Xauthority:rw" openquantumsafe/wireshark
```


And I'm getting this error,

```
No protocol specified
21:23:24.408     Main Warn could not connect to display :0
21:23:24.408     Main Info Could not load the Qt platform plugin "xcb" in "" even though it was found.
Aborted (core dumped)
```

Kindly please help me with this error.

Thanks in advance.

comment.body:
Just followed my own advice and everything works (for me):
Run `docker run --rm --net=host --privileged --env="DISPLAY" --volume="$HOME/.Xauthority:/root/.Xauthority:rw" -it ubuntu` and in that image run `apt update && apt install -y qtop`. Afterwards, `qtop` should bring up a window OK. If that works, "openquantumsafe/wireshark" should also work. If it doesn't, please let us know.

issue.title: Memory leaks during key creation and signing
issue.body:
Hi, 
we are currently developing a crypto api and found some memory leaks with valgrind during key creation with pqc algorithms.

The leaks we found:
- During `EVP_PKEY_keygen_init` in  **oqs_kmgmt.c**, line 422 
`gctx->oqs_name = OPENSSL_strdup(oqs_name);`
- During `EVP_PKEY_generate` in **oqsprov_keys.c**, line 618
`ret->tls_name = OPENSSL_strdup(tls_name);`
- During `EVP_DigestSignInit` from `ASN1_item_i2d` in **oqs_sig.c**
Not able to fix it, but we assume its coming from line 156: `ctx->aid_len = get_aid(&(ctx->aid), ctx->sig->tls_name);`, from a not correctly freed `aid`.


We started with version *0.4.0* of the oqs-provider, when we saw that there are memory leaks fixed on [commit](https://github.com/levitte/tmp-oqsprov/commit/3d573cc2862c66d513edde21d447692d85678d60), we switched to the current [main](https://github.com/levitte/tmp-oqsprov/commit/277b3719686c16e60c24ad8b4e82f18ec3778a1e) version. The leaks listed above also occurred there.

comment.body: @baentsch Do i have the permissions to create a branch in this repository? I have fixed it locally but cannot push it.
